column4: can i use the notification area to display a welcome message? what command is used to call it?
hi
you can use notify-send in a shell.  There are libnotify bindings in many languages if you prefer

dell 1907FP

dunno, this one was kinda pinched from the nhs lol

one better: http://support.dell.com/support/edocs/systems/1907FP/en/setup.htm#Connecting%20Your%20Monitor
that's a dumb thing to do really. dependencies are dependencies for a reason.  Give more details
the dependency is not satisfiable, it has no installation candidate and recommends using the newer version (which i have)
give more details.  pastebin errors etc
im giving you all i have, i downloaded a deb of maniadrive, it needs a dependency, when i try to install said dependency i get this http://paste.ubuntu.com/88046/
where did you get it?  I can't find a deb on maniadrive's site

the deb is for hardy
so
so it's not intended to be used with intrepid since deps may be broken as you just found out.  Get the source package and try to rebuild it if you want
id prefer to forcefully install it regardless of the dep first
install it properly, it will save you headaches later
thankyou for your suggestion, but do you know how to forcefullly install a deb regardless of dependencies or not?
I don't help people do things they shouldn't do sorry
this is my computer, there is nothing (legal) i 'shouldnt' do
I didn't say anything about legality...

no but you not answering someones question because you think they shouldnt do it seems like a strange policy, i would agree with things like not telling them how to rm rf there hard drive due to this channels rules however if someone asks a legitimate question i would warn them of consequences 'and' give them there answer, i will no longer discuss this, in this channel, your choice if you want to continue, just tell me where
~/.config/autostart/ but you would need to create a desktop file (see the freedesktop.org spec).  Depending on what you want to do, you can use ~/.gnomerc or ~/.xprofile instead.
im writing a qotd script. is graphical and i want it to run when i log in, i also plan to make it into a .deb so automation of the starting at login is pretty crucial
thanks for the links, il check em out
it's trivial to do in zsh.  In bash, you probably need to do some awkward piping
yeah, i thought it might resort ot that
zsh is a nice shell.  In zsh you can do: mv ^folder folder  to do what you said for example
hmm, i might think about using it, thanks
checking...
ubiquity maybe...?
if you mean a real terminal, you might try yaquake or tilda
can they be embeded in firefox?
no, but they pop out from the top of your screen like the console in quake
ubiquity is not really what I want -- I want to be able to run vim in firefox to do some coding without having to open another app
give those two thing I mentioned a try... I think they will satisfy you.  You may also want to try vimperator.  You can then edit input boxes in vim and control firefox like vim
yeah ive used that.. and i assume the two terminal apps behave like fluxbox does anyway yeah? double click to hide
I didn't use them much.  I thought you just assigned some keyboard shortcut for them
oh, well .. thanks jrib :)
use fluxbox as the window manager in gnome?
I would love to, but I cant find any 'recent' documentation on how to do so, can you assist?
I haven't done it in a while, but fluxbox wiki used to have a guide iirc
yeah, I found a few links to such an article, but it seems dead now
one way to set window manager is "export WINDOW_MANAGER=/path/to/window/manager" in ~/.gnomerc.  There may be other things you wish to do as well
http://fluxbox-wiki.org/index.php?title=FAQ#Can_I_use_fluxbox_as_the_window_manager_in_GNOME different approach
brilliant, I will try, thank you

just thought I would let you know, the fluxbox wiki has incorrect information, but if I enter exec=/usr/bin/startfluxbox  into a (may need to be created) ~/.gnomerc and then uninstall gnome-panel everything works like a charm!!! thank you so much
hmm, you should be able to use gnome-panel though
did you try what I said
yeah, you can use the panel, but it screws with fluxbox a wee bit. I use dual screens so things were a bit strange. what do you mean 'try what I said'?
one way to set window manager is "export WINDOW_MANAGER=/path/to/window/manager" in ~/.gnomerc.  There may be other things you wish to do as well
that is what I did, dont know what the 'other things' were though
you can ignore that
then your instructions were near perfect... again :)
i think i saw a howto on the forums that might address the panel issue if you care
hit me :)
use 'at'

at probably runs in some limited environment (check)
